p: Agriculture also emits a disproportionately high percentage of Iowa’s overall GHGs relative to other states. Whereas agriculture directly generates about 7% of US GHGs through activities such as enteric fermentation in ruminant livestock, manure management, and use of nitrogen fertilizers ( USEPA, 2013, p. 6-1), in 2011, direct emissions of GHGs from agriculture comprised 26% of Iowa’s overall GHG emissions ( Iowa Department of Natural Resources [IDNR], 2012, p. 3). Fifty-nine percent of agricultural GHGs stemmed from soil management for grain production and the balance from livestock production and waste ( IDNR, 2012, p. 5). These activities primarily generate the potent GHGs CH 4 and N 2O, which have “global warming potentials” 21 and 310 times that of CO 2, respectively ( Forster et al., 2007, p. 212). Thus, Iowa also provides an appropriate context for examining farmer attitudes toward mitigation action.
